subject: Back to School!
header: this is the first day of school in many countries and kids roam the streets determined to improve their knowledge. Or at least to meet some friends they have not seen for a while.
It's a bit like a New Year. You can have all kinds of 'resolutions'. I hope we'll tons of new and exciting articles about Perl and how it is used to solve various 'real-world' problems.

entries.title: Replacing hash keys with values does not a translation make
entries.text: Sinan Unur (Sinan) thinks the Turkish translation of the Perl Maven pages actually harm would-be programmers. Naturally I disagree, but he has a point: Bad translations can indeed harm people. The only thing I can do is to suggest to collaborate with other translators to improve the text. It is available in GitHub

entries.title: Context dependence in Turkish
entries.text: As a follow-up to the previous post, and after patching the Turkish translation, Sinan goes on discussing context sensitivity in the Turkish language.

entries.title: Continous Integration with Travis CI and Github for Distzillians
entries.text: You can configure your GitHub repositories to run your test automatically every time you push out code or even if someone sends a pull-request. By this you can have our module tested on various versions of perl long before you release a new version. Very useful!

entries.title: Yearly boards and fallen authors
entries.text: Philippe Bruhat (BooK) likes games and now with his new site, cpan.io, he has a lot of new ground to create competitions. This one is showing how long each person will release a CPAN module every week within a year. A major limitation that I can see is that this board only handles years according to the Gregorian calendar. In any case this is for the CPAN heavy-weights. If you have ideas for other competitions to encourage more ad-hoc contributions, or if you have any other idea, please open a ticket!

entries.title: Link to public version control system (GitHub or otherwise)
entries.text: Having the META files include a link to your public VCS will let MetaCPAN to link to it and will make it easier for others to send patches.

entries.title: Finding all Plack Middleware or Perl::Critic Policies
entries.text: It is probably just me being too slow to learn this, but apparently you can list all the modules in a given name-space by preceding it with 'module:'. So it is quite easy to list all the Plack::Middleware, all the Perl::Critic::Policy modules, or all the plugins for Dancer, Mojolicious, or Catalyst.
